newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australian retailers, investors welcome rate cut.
newsitem.headline: Australian retailers, investors welcome rate cut.

text.p: Australian retailers on Friday they welcomed the Reserve Bank of Australia's (RBA) decision to cut interest rates by 0.5 percentage points to 5.5 percent.
The retail index of the Australian Stock Exchange was up 1.3 percent at midday. The overall market, as measured by The All Ordinaries Index, was up 0.3 percent.

"It's received very positively. Coming on top of the two interest rate cuts in late 1996 this is a further injection into the economy which will hopefully engender consumer confidence," Woolworths managing director Reg Clairs told Reuters.
Clairs said it would take time for the effect of the cut to filter through to disposable income.
"We are now only just starting to feel the positive effects of those rate cuts late last year," Clairs said.

Chris Bennett, general manager finance of West Australian wholesaler Foodland Associated Ltd also welcomed the cut. "We believe that the RBA has correctly anticipated that the level of unemployment in the economy is too high," Bennett said.
Australia's unemployment rate remained at 8.7 percent in April. Friday's rate cut was the fourth in less than a year, with rates being cut by a total of two percentage points.
Bennett said because Foodland traded only in Western Australia and New Zealand, it would not be as affected by the decision as other retailers.
"In Western Australia unemployment is considerably lower than the rest of Australia so the rate cut is probably likely to have less effect in this state than other states," he said.

Bennett said he expected the effect of the cut to be almost immediate. "It's a clear sign to people that they can expect lower rates on their credit cards and their housing interest rates are going to fall," he said.

But Gerry Harvey, chairman of retail and retail franchisor, Havey Norman Ltd told Reuters the cut was too little and too late. "They had to do it they didn't have any choice. I would like to see another one percent cut tomorrow," Harvey said.
"Unless business picks up this second half they are going to have to keep dropping it," he said. Harvey said the previous rate cuts had had no effect on the company's sales.
"Normally when you drop these things you do get an effect but this has being going on for a year with no effect," he said.
Harvey said he believed official interest rates should be at about 4.5 percent.
"The reality of it is that I'm out there in the market place and I know what is happening and they (RBA) know what is happening three or four months later and they are reacting to that," Harvey said.
He said he would be surprised if the latest cut had any immediate effect on sales but was hopeful things would improve.
At 1.00 p.m (0350 GMT), Woolworths shares were 12 cents higher at A$3.98, Foodland shares were 20 cents higher at A$7.95 while Harvey Norman stock was seven cents up at A$6.75.
Shares in Coles Myer Ltd, the largest of the retailers, were up a cent at A$A$5.96.
